speakers.about: Tanay Pant is an author, hacker, developer and tech enthusiast. He is best known for his work on ‚ÄúLearning Web-based Virtual Reality‚Äù by Apress, ‚ÄúBuilding a Virtual Assistant for Raspberry Pi‚Äù by Apress and ‚ÄúLearning Firefox OS Application Development‚Äù published by Packt. He is also an official representative of Mozilla. He has been listed in the about:credits of the Firefox web browser for his contributions to the different open source projects of the Mozilla Foundation. He also writes for a number of websites like SitePoint and Tuts+ where he shares tips and tricks about web development.

Graduated from SPBGPU, Konstantin used to be fond of microcontrollers and circuitry. He has started coding for android platform since 2.2 version had been released. Today, Kostya is an architect in the St. Petersburg team Redmadrobot
Android Developer with over five years of professional experience and love of creating extremely high-quality apps with perfect UI / UX and optimizations. Working at Yandex. GDG Leader.

Google Developer Expert.

Doug is a leading mobile developer advocate and evangelist. He is widely known as an expert in mobile application architecture, especially when it comes to performance. Doug has worked with thounited-states-of-americands of developers around the world, helping them improve the speed, battery life and customer satisfaction of their applications (both native and web). The author of O‚ÄôReilly‚Äôs ‚ÄòHigh Performance Android Apps,‚Äô he has spoken at conferences around the world on mobile performance. He is currently freelancing,and traveling with his family of 6 (plus the dog!) as a digital nomad in Europe.

Dora is a senior developer at the Financial Times. She has recently led the team responsible for implementing the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) on ft.com, and currently works on exciting internal products. She is passionate about all things web performance ‚Äì and skydiving.

Currently Sergey is an independent Android Engineer and Consultant with the background in backend dev. Co-organiser of the first Kotlin User Group in Russia and Android Academy in St. Petersburg and Moscow, usually speaks about Kotlin & Android. Kotlin early adopter, digital nomad.

14 years of JS everywhere: from microcontrollers to rendering video in the cloud. More than 5 years of educational experience (at two universities and Illya's own courses), Ph.D. in Computer Science (field of interest: System Analysis and Theory of optimal decisions). Coach at Kottans.Org project.

talks.title: Multiplayer games with WebXR
talks.description: Virtual Reality is a technology used for building realistic experiences for games, environments, content display as well as marketing. In this session, I will teach the participants about 3D objects in the web, virtual reality, VR devices, WebVR, WebVR API and finally building games with A-Frame. In this talk, I will also showcase creating a multiplayer game similar to Pokemon Go using WebXR in a live coding session. The live coding session will cover topics such as creating the game scene, importing 3D objects, interaction with objects, adding animations, implementing WebAR and adding multiplayer capability to the game with real time databases. By the end of the session, the participants will have a complete understanding of what WebXR is and they will be able to create cross-browser WebXR experiences as well as multiplayer games similar to Pokemon Go.
talks.speaker: tanay-pant

talks.title: Breaking news: A web performance story
talks.description: At the Financial Times we built one of the world's fastest news websites. This talk sheds light on the unique challenges of optimising web performance for a highly componentised micro frontends architecture with a rapid release cycle and a common toolchain that punishes dissent. We‚Äôll explore how we deliver and build ft.com, along with the underlying architectural and organisational decisions and their implications to high availability, high reliability, and optimal performance. This is an opportunity to learn about the payoffs and trade-offs we made along the way, and what the future holds.
talks.speaker: dora-militaru

talks.title: Delivering Fast and Beautiful Images and Video
talks.description: The average mobile website page weight is ~50% images. Toss in the complication of thousands of differently sized screens, and it might appear that efficient delivery of images to every device is an impossible task. But all is not lost! In this talk, we‚Äôll examine strategies to send the perfect image to every device, ensuring a fast, beautiful rendering of your content. We‚Äôll look at progressive images, placeholder images, lazy loading and other techniques and real world examples that will improve the usability of your site or app. Attendees will come away with an understand of the current ‚Äòstate of the art‚Äô for optimizing visual content on the web.
talks.speaker: doug-sillars

talks.title: There once was Swift
talks.description: We live with Swift in a fifth version of which we are promised to have the stability of the binary interface and happiness. But how can we use all these exciting things for greater good? One can program differently and it is not clear which way is the right one. How to know where the pitfalls are? Why are they there? And are these real pitfalls or just imaginary? Lets take a look together.
talks.speaker: shurik-babaev
